title: Pretty-printing of `Fn*` traits in diagnostics leaks unstable details

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

body:
```rust
fn f(_: impl Fn(i32, i32) -> i32) {}
fn g() { f(0) }
```

The current output is:

```
error[E0277]: expected a `Fn<(i32, i32)>` closure, found `{integer}`
 --> <source>:2:12
  |
1 | fn f(_: impl Fn(i32, i32) -> i32) {}
  |              ------------------- required by this bound in `f`
2 | fn g() { f(0) }
  |            ^ expected an `Fn<(i32, i32)>` closure, found `{integer}`
  |
  = help: the trait `Fn<(i32, i32)>` is not implemented for `{integer}`

error: aborting due to previous error

For more information about this error, try `rustc --explain E0277`.
Compiler returned: 1
```

<!-- The following is not always necessary. -->
Ideally the output should look like:

Same as above, but `Fn<(i32, i32)>` should be `Fn(i32, i32) -> i32`.

Compare with a fnptr instead of a closure:
```
error[E0308]: mismatched types
 --> <source>:3:13
  |
3 | fn g() { f2(0) }
  |             ^ expected fn pointer, found `usize`
  |
  = note: expected fn pointer `fn(i32, i32) -> i32`
                   found type `usize`

error: aborting due to previous error

For more information about this error, try `rustc --explain E0308`.
Compiler returned: 1
```

Seems like it would be straightforward to special case `core::ops::Fn*` et. al., especially since they're lang items. Clearly we already do, since rustc suggests that it should be a closure.
